problem.description: pip-audit cannot parse pyproject.toml with uv package manager
problem.error_pattern: ERROR:pip_audit._cli:requirement file pyproject.toml contains invalid specifier
problem.context: Modern Python projects using pyproject.toml with uv package manager

solution.description: Export dependencies to requirements.txt format before running pip-audit
solution.code:
uv pip freeze > requirements-audit.txt
uv run pip-audit -r requirements-audit.txt --desc
alternative_solutions: uv export --format requirements-txt > requirements.txt && pip-audit -r requirements.txt

patterns.documentation: pip-audit expects requirements.txt format. Modern Python projects using pyproject.toml need to export dependencies to requirements.txt format first.

problem.description: Using PEP 735 --group syntax with PEP 621 optional-dependencies structure
problem.error_pattern: error: Group `(\w+)` is not defined in the project's `dependency-groups` table
problem.context: CI workflows using uv sync --group with [project.optional-dependencies]

solution.description: Replace --group with --extra in uv sync commands
alternative_solutions: Manually update each uv sync command to use --extra

patterns.documentation: uv supports two dependency group formats: PEP 735 [dependency-groups] (use --group) and PEP 621 [project.optional-dependencies] (use --extra). Match the syntax to your pyproject.toml structure.

problem.description: Transform tests failing due to make_copy parameter not being respected
problem.error_pattern: AssertionError: Arrays are not equal|Original array was modified
problem.context: Data preprocessing transforms not correctly handling array copying

solution.description: REQUIRES MANUAL INVESTIGATION - Likely need to fix transform implementation to properly handle make_copy parameter
recommended_actions: Check if make_copy parameter is properly propagated
Verify array copying logic (np.copy vs array.copy)
Test with different NumPy versions to identify regression
Review recent commit history for transform changes

metadata.deferred_reason: Requires domain knowledge of transform design intent

patterns.documentation: Transform copy semantics may have changed with dependency version updates. Investigation needed to determine if tests or implementation is incorrect.

problem.description: Gitleaks secret scanning fails due to shallow Git clone missing parent commit
problem.error_pattern: fatal: ambiguous argument '.*\^\.\..+'): unknown revision or path not in the working tree
problem.context: GitHub Actions with default fetch-depth: 1 (shallow clone)

solution.description: NOT AN AUTO-FIXABLE CODE ISSUE - Transient CI infrastructure problem
recommended_actions: Increase fetch-depth in actions/checkout step (e.g., fetch-depth: 2 or fetch-depth: 0)
Configure gitleaks to scan only current commit instead of range
Wait for next commit - issue often self-resolves

patterns.documentation: Gitleaks action automatically determines commit range based on push event. With shallow clones (fetch-depth: 1), parent commits may not be available, causing transient failures. This is not a code issue.

problem.description: Backend integration tests fail due to incomplete JAX mocking when numpyro import chain requires extensive JAX submodules
problem.context: Integration tests mocking JAX to test backend platform detection, but quantiq imports trigger numpyro which needs comprehensive JAX mock

solution.description: REQUIRES TEST ARCHITECTURE REDESIGN - Tests need either comprehensive JAX mock or module import isolation
recommended_actions: Option 1: Add all required JAX submodules to sys.modules mock (jax.tree_util, jax.lax, jax.random, etc.)
Option 2: Isolate backend module testing from full quantiq package imports
Option 3: Use pytest fixtures to provide comprehensive JAX mock infrastructure
Option 4: Mock at a higher level - mock get_device_info() instead of JAX itself

patterns.documentation: Backend integration tests mock JAX to simulate different platform/CUDA configurations. However, quantiq package imports pull in numpyro which requires extensive JAX submodules. Tests need architectural improvements to properly isolate or comprehensively mock the JAX dependency chain.

problem.description: Windows PowerShell fails to parse Bash-style backslash line continuation in multi-line commands
problem.context: GitHub Actions workflow steps using Bash syntax on Windows runners without explicit shell specification

solution.description: Add explicit shell: bash specification to workflow steps using Bash syntax
solution.code:
# Add after 'run:' block in workflow step
shell: bash
alternative_solutions: Remove backslash and use single-line command
Use PowerShell-style backtick (`) for line continuation
Use YAML multi-line string without line continuation characters

patterns.documentation: Windows runners in GitHub Actions default to PowerShell, which uses different line continuation syntax than Bash. When using Bash syntax (backslash \), explicitly specify 'shell: bash' in the workflow step. PowerShell interprets -- as a unary operator, causing parse errors. This is a common regression when refactoring workflow YAML without preserving shell specifications.

learning_notes: pip-audit works best with requirements.txt format, not pyproject.toml
uv package manager requires export step for compatibility with pip-based tools
Test failures related to data mutation require careful investigation before auto-fixing
Deleting uv.lock can expose latent bugs by changing dependency versions
Security scanning tools may have different input format requirements than modern package managers
uv sync --group is for PEP 735 [dependency-groups], --extra is for PEP 621 [project.optional-dependencies]
Always match CI workflow syntax to pyproject.toml structure
sed syntax differs between Linux (-i) and macOS (-i '')
CRITICAL: Always check if test failures are PRE-EXISTING by examining previous CI runs before attempting auto-fix
Gitleaks failures with 'unknown revision' in shallow clones are transient CI issues, not code bugs
Integration test mocking must account for full import chain, not just the module being tested directly
When quantiq package is imported, it triggers numpyro imports which require extensive JAX submodule mocking
Distinguish between: (1) code bugs, (2) pre-existing test failures, (3) transient CI issues before applying fixes
Compare current run failures with previous commit's run failures to identify NEW vs. PRE-EXISTING issues
CRITICAL: Windows runners default to PowerShell - always specify 'shell: bash' when using Bash syntax (backslash line continuation)
PowerShell interprets -- at line start as unary operator, not command argument - causes parse errors with multi-line commands
Workflow YAML refactoring can introduce shell specification regressions - preserve explicit shell settings
yamllint fixes focusing on formatting can accidentally remove important shell specifications

fix_history.analysis: All failures were either transient CI issues or pre-existing test failures. Commit 25a0362 only contained safe linting fixes and did not introduce new failures.

fix_history.solution_applied: add shell: bash to test step
fix_history.analysis: New PowerShell parse error discovered on Windows runners. Regression from commit 944a7da which reformatted workflow YAML but removed shell specification. Auto-fixed by adding explicit shell: bash.
